#D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:01.44%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt;text-align:center;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">$</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:11.02%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt;text-align:right;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">-</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:00.60%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt;text-align:right;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:01.44%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt;text-align:center;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">$</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:11.02%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>1,035&nbsp; </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:01.08%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt;text-align:right;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:27.52%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Accrued expense and other current liabilities and other liabilities</font></p> </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 6pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">Non-Recurring Fair Value Measurements</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The majority of our non-financial instruments, which include inventories, property and equipment and intangible assets, are not required to be carried at fair value on a recurring basis. However, if certain triggering events occur such that a non-financial instrument is required to be evaluated for impairment and the carrying value is not recoverable, the carrying value would be adjusted to the lower of its cost or fair value and an impairment charge would be recorded. See Note 3 &#x2013; Property and Equipment and Note 4 &#x2013; Goodwill &amp; Intangible Assets for discussions on impairment charges recorded during the periods presented.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Management Estimates</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;The preparation of financial statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America (&#x201C;GAAP&#x201D;) requires management to make estimates, judgments and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting period. Management believes that the estimates, judgments and assumptions made when accounting for items and matters such as, but not limited to, the allowance for doubtful accounts, sales returns, impairment assessments and charges, recoverability of assets (including deferred tax assets), uncertain tax positions, share-based compensation expense, the assessment of lower of cost or market on inventory, useful lives assigned to long-lived assets, depreciation and provisions for contingencies are reasonable based on information available at the time they are made. Management also makes estimates in the assessments of potential losses in relation to tax </font><font style="display: inline;">and customs </font><font style="display: inline;">matters and threatened or pending legal proceedings (see Note&nbsp;15&#x2014;Legal Proceedings). Actual results could materially differ from these estimates. For matters not related to income taxes, if a loss is considered probable and the amount can be reasonably estimated, we recognize an expense for the estimated loss. If there is the potential to recover a portion of the estimated loss from a third party, we make a separate assessment of recoverability and reduce the estimated loss if recovery is deemed probable.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Fair Value</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Fair value is the price that would be received from the sale of an asset or transfer of a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. When determining the fair value measurements for assets and liabilities which are required to be recorded at fair value, we consider the principal or most advantageous market in which a hypothetical sale or transfer would take place and consider assumptions that market participants would use when pricing the asset or liability, such as inherent risk, transfer restrictions, and risk of non-performance.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The fair value hierarchy is made up of three levels of inputs which may be used to measure fair value: </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Level&nbsp;1&#x2014;observable inputs such as quoted prices for identical instruments in active markets; </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Level&nbsp;2&#x2014;observable inputs such as quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active and model derived valuations in which all significant inputs are observable in active markets; and </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Level&nbsp;3&#x2014;unobservable inputs for which there is little or no market data and which require us to develop our own assumptions. We categorize fair value measurements within the fair value hierarchy based upon the lowest level of the most significant inputs used to </font><font style="display: inline;">determine such fair value measurement.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt; font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Cash equivalents primarily include time deposits and certificates of deposit with original maturities of three months or less. Time deposits and certificates of deposit included in cash equivalents are valued at amortized cost, which approximates fair value. These investments have been classified as a Level 1 measurement.</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Derivative financial instruments are required to be recorded at their fair value, on a recurring basis. The fair values of our derivative instruments are determined using a discounted cash flow valuation model. The significant inputs used in the model are readily available in public markets or can be derived from observable market transactions, and therefore, have been classified as Level&nbsp;2. These inputs include the applicable exchange rates and forward rates, and discount rates based on the prevailing LIBOR deposit rates.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Our other financial instruments are not required to be carried at fair value on a recurring basis. The carrying value of these financial instruments, including cash equivalents, accounts receivable, accounts payable and accrued liabilities, approximates fair value due to their short maturities. Based on borrowing rates currently available to us, with similar terms, the carrying values of capital lease obligations and the line of credit approximate their fair values.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Inventories and long-lived assets such as property and equipment and intangible assets are also not required to be carried at fair value on a recurring basis. For a discussion of inventory estimated fair value see &#x201C;Inventory Valuation&#x201D; below. However, when determining impairment losses, the fair values of property and equipment and intangibles must be determined. For such determination, we </font><font style="display: inline;">geneally </font><font style="display: inline;">use either an income approach with inputs that are mainly unobservable, such as expected future cash flows, or a market approach using observable inputs such as replacement cost or third party appraisals, as appropriate. Estimated future cash flows are based on management&#x2019;s operating budgets and forecasts which take into consideration both observable and unobservable inputs including growth rates, pricing, new markets and other factors expected to affect the business, as well as management&#x2019;s forecasts for inventory, receivables, capital spending, and other cash needs.</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">See Note&nbsp;6</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;</font><font style="display: inline;">Fair Value Measurements</font><font style="display: inline;"> for further discussion related to </font><font style="display: inline;">fair value measurements.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 36170000 4743000 2994000 22156000 5641000 636000 49169000 4856000 3522000 33933000 6222000 636000 4771000 14956000 5689000 8531000 10003000 13139000 84700000 4743000 6109000 66530000 6321000 997000 106258000 4856000 6161000 87426000 7145000 670000 48530000 3115000 44374000 680000 361000 57089000 2639000 53493000 923000 34000 596000 596000 5548000 5548000 1035000 1035000 295000 295000 2325000 4886000 -2500000 -1334000 11892000 -13928000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Foreign Currency Translation and Foreign Currency Transactions</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Our </font><font style="display: inline;">reporting</font><font style="display: inline;"> currency is the U.S. dollar. Assets and liabilities of foreign operations denominated in local currencies are translated at the rate of exchange at the balance sheet date. Revenues and expenses are translated at the weighted average rate of exchange during the applicable period. Adjustments resulting from translating foreign functional currency financial statements into U.S. dollars are included in the foreign currency translation adjustment, a component of accumulated other comprehensive income in stockholders&#x2019; equity. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Gains and losses generated by transactions denominated in </font><font style="display: inline;">currencies other than the local functional</font><font style="display: inline;"> currencies are reflected in the consolidated statement of operations in the period in which they occur and are primarily associated with payables and receivables arising from intercompany transa</font><font style="display: inline;">ctions.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 16196000 20827000 540000 -7200000 2729000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p><p style="page-break-after:always">&nbsp;</p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;background-color:lime;"></font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">4. GOODWILL &amp; INTANGIBLE ASSETS</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">T</font><font style="display: inline;">he following table summarizes the goodwill and identifiable intangible assets as of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012 and 2011</font><font style="display: inline;">:</font> </p> <p <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <sup style="display: inline;">(3)</sup><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">On July 16, 2012, our subsidiaries Crocs Europe B.V., Crocs Stores B.V. and Crocs Belgium N.V. (collectively referred to as Crocs Europe), which are part of our Europe segment, acquired certain net assets and activities from Crocs Benelux B.V. (Benelux) pursuant to a sale and pu</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">rchase agreement dated July 9, 2012.&nbsp; Prior to the acquisition, Benelux was a distributor of the Company.&nbsp; The Company acquired&nbsp; Benelux&#x2019; retail business and wholesale business, including inventory, fixed assets, customer relationships, 10 retail stores and their associated leases.&nbsp; Total consideration paid was cash </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">of &#x20AC; </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">3.6</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;"> million (approximately $</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">4.6</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;"> million).</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">During the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010</font><font style="display: inline;">, amortization expense recorded for intangible assets with finite lives was </font><font style="display: inline;">$</font><font style="display: inline;">13.6</font><font style="display: inline;"> million,</font><font style="display: inline;"> &nbsp;$</font><font style="display: inline;">9.8</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">7.6</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, respectively, of whi</font><font style="display: inline;">ch $</font><font style="display: inline;">4.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million,</font><font style="display: inline;"> &nbsp;$</font><font style="display: inline;">2.9</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.3</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million wa</font><font style="display: inline;">s recorded in cost of sales, respectively. The remaining amounts were recorded in selling, general and administrative expenses. </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:2pt double #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>57,089&nbsp; </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt; font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Intangible Assets</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&#x2014;Intangible assets that are determined to have finite lives are amortized over their useful lives on a straight-line basis. Customer relationships are amortized on a straight-line basis or an accelerated basis. Indefinite lived intangible assets, such as trade names, are not amortized and are evaluated for impairment at least annually and when circumstances imply possible impairment. </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Amortization of manufacturing intangible assets is included in cost of sales on the consolidated statements of operations. Amortization related to corporate, non-product and non-manufacturing assets such as our global information systems is included in selling, general and administrative expenses on the consolidated statements of operations. The following table sets forth our definite lived intangible assets and the periods over which they are amortized.</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" align="center" style="border-collapse:collapse;width: 75.00%;margin-left:0pt;"> <tr> <td valign="bottom" style="width:215.00pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 1pt;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:8pt;">Intangible Asset Class</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:195.40pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 1pt;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000 ;text-align:center;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:8pt;">Weighted Average Amortization Period</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top" style="width:215.00pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 10pt;text-indent: -10pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:-10pt; width:192.65pt; overflow: hidden; white-space: nowrap;"><font style="display: inline;">Patents</font>.............................................................................</font><font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:0pt; width:-1pt;text-align:right"><font style="display: inline;"></font></font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:195.40pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">10&nbsp;years</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top" style="width:215.00pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 10pt;text-indent: -10pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:-10pt; width:192.65pt; overflow: hidden; white-space: nowrap;"><font style="display: inline;">Customer relationships</font>.............................................</font><font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:0pt; width:-1pt;text-align:right"><font style="display: inline;"></font></font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:195.40pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Estimated customer life</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top" style="width:215.00pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 10pt;text-indent: -10pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:-10pt; width:192.65pt; overflow: hidden; white-space: nowrap;"><font style="display: inline;">Core technology</font>...........................................................</font><font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:0pt; width:-1pt;text-align:right"><font style="display: inline;"></font></font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:195.40pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">5&nbsp;years</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top" style="width:215.00pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 10pt;text-indent: -10pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:-10pt; width:192.65pt; overflow: hidden; white-space: nowrap;"><font style="display: inline;">Non-competition agreement</font>....................................</font><font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:0pt; width:-1pt;text-align:right"><font style="display: inline;"></font></font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:195.40pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Contractual term</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top" style="width:215.00pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 10pt;text-indent: -10pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:-10pt; width:192.65pt; overflow: hidden; white-space: nowrap;"><font style="display: inline;">Capitalized software</font>...................................................</font><font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:0pt; width:-1pt;text-align:right"><font style="display: inline;"></font></font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:195.40pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Shorter of 7&nbsp;years or useful life</font></p> </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 12pt 31.5pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">Capitalized Software</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;We capitalize certain internal and external software acquisition and development costs, including the costs of employees and contractors devoting time to the software development projects and external direct costs for materials and services. Initial costs associated with internally-developed-and-used software are expensed until it is determined that the project has reached the application development stage. Once in its development stage, subsequent additions, modifications or upgrades to an internal-use software project are capitalized to the extent that they add functionality. Software maintenance and training costs are expensed in the period in which they are incurred. Capitalized software primarily consists of our enterprise resource system software, warehouse management software and point of sale software. At least annually, we consider the potential impairment of capitalized software by assessing the substantive service potential of the software, changes, if any, in the extent or manner in which the software is used or is expected to be used, and the actual cost of software development or modification compared to expected cost. See Note&nbsp;4&#x2014;Goodwill and Intangible Assets for further discussion.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 12pt 31.5pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">Impairment of Intangible Assets</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Intangible assets with indefinite lives are evaluated for impairment when events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be fully recoverable and at least annually. Intangible assets that are determined to have definite lives are amortized over their useful lives and are evaluated for impairment only when events or circumstances indicate a carrying value may not be fully recoverable. Recoverability is based on the estimated future undiscounted cash flows of the asset. If the asset is not supported on an undiscounted cash flow basis, the amount of impairment is measured as the difference between its carrying value and its fair value.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Goodwill</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;</font><font style="display: inline;">Goodwill</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;"> represents the excess purchase price paid over the fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed in acquisitions</font><font style="display: inline;">. Goodwill is</font><font style="display: inline;"> considered an indefinite lived asset and therefore is not amortized.&nbsp; </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">The Company assesses goodwill for impairment annually on the last day of the fourth quarter, or more frequently if events and circumstances indicate impairment may have occurred. If the carrying value of goodwill exceeds its implied fair value, the Company records an impairment loss equal to the difference. See </font><font style="display: inline;">Note&nbsp;4</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;</font><font style="display: inline;">Goodwill</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;"> and Intangible Assets for discussion of goodwill balances. There was no impairment of goodwill for the year ended</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 423764000 119206000 536410000 170218000 147175000 99811000 144799000 607977000 196085000 160743000 106350000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Impairment of Long-Lived Assets</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Long-lived assets to be held and used are evaluated for impairment when events or circumstances indicate the carrying value of a long-lived asset may not be fully recoverable. Events that may indicate the impairment of a long-lived asset (or asset group, as defined below) include; (i)&nbsp;a significant decrease in its market price, (ii)&nbsp;a significant adverse change in the extent or manner in which it is being used or in its physical condition, (iii)&nbsp;a significant adverse change in legal factors or business climate that could affect its value, including an adverse action or assessment by a regulator, (iv)&nbsp;an accumulation of costs significantly in excess of the amount originally expected for its acquisition or construction, (v)&nbsp;its current period operating or cash flow losses combined with historical operating or cash flow losses or a forecast of its cash flows demonstrate continuing losses associated with its use, and (vi)&nbsp;a current expectation that, more likely than not, it will be sold or otherwise disposed of significantly before the end of its previously estimated useful life. If such facts indicate a potential impairment of a long-lived asset (or asset group), we assess the recoverability by determining if its carrying value exceeds the sum of its projected undiscounted cash flows from its use and eventual disposition over its remaining economic life. If the asset is not supported on an undiscounted cash flow basis, the amount of impairment is measured as the difference between its carrying value and its fair value. Assets held for sale are reported at the lower of the carrying amount or fair value less costs to sell. Assets to be abandoned or from which no further benefit is expected are written down to zero at the time that the determination is made and the assets are removed entirely from service.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">An asset group is the lowest level of assets and liabilities for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the cash flows of other assets and liabilities.&nbsp; </font><font style="display: inline;">For assets involved in our retail business our asset group is at the retail store level.</font><font style="display: inline;"> See Note 3 &#x2013; Property and Equipment for a discussion of impairment losses recorded during the periods presented.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> -14835000 -12057000 12060000 95627000 148747000 133488000 80792000 136690000 145548000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 15pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p><p style="page-break-after:always">&nbsp;</p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 15pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;"></font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 15pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">1</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">1. style="width:02.74%;border-top:2pt double #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt;text-align:center;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:13.58%;border-top:2pt double #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> &nbsp;</p> </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="middle" <font style="display: inline;font-family:Arial;">$</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:13.58%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>(1,009) </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="middle" style="width:61.88%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt 6pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Total non-current deferred tax liabilities </font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:02.74%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;padding:0pt;"> <p 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">$</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:13.58%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:2pt double #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>(779) </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:02.74%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:02.74%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">$</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:13.58%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:2pt double #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>(1,009) </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">We do not provide for deferred taxes on the excess of the financial reporting basis over the tax basis in our investments in foreign subsidiaries that are essentially permanent in duration. In general, it is our practice and intention to reinvest the earnings of our foreign subsidiaries in those operations. Generally, the earnings of our foreign subsidiaries become subject to U.S. taxation upon the remittance of dividends and under certain other circumstances. Exceptions may be made on a year-by-year basis to repatriate current year earnings of certain foreign subsidiaries based on cash needs in the U.S. As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012</font><font style="display: inline;">, we have provided for deferred U.S. income tax </font><font style="display: inline;">of $</font><font style="display: inline;">7.6</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;m</font><font style="display: inline;">illion </font><font style="display: inline;">on $</font><font style="display: inline;">38.6</font><font style="display: inline;"> &nbsp;m</font><font style="display: inline;">illion of foreign subsidiary earnings. No withholding tax is due with respect to the repatriation of these earnings to the U.S. and none has been provided for.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">At </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012 and 2011</font><font style="display: inline;">, U.S. income and foreign withholding taxes have not been provided </font><font style="display: inline;">on for approximately $</font><font style="display: inline;">490.8</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">371.0</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, respectively, of unremitted earnings of subsidiaries operating outside of the U.S. These earnings are estimated to represent the excess of the financial reporting over the tax basis in our investments in those subsidiaries. These earnings, which are considered to be indefinitely reinvested, would become subject to U.S. income tax if they were remitted to the U.S. The amount of unrecognized deferred U.S. income tax liability on the unremitted earnings has not been determined because the hypothetical calculation is not practicable.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">We have deferred tax assets related to certain deductible temporary differences in various tax jurisdictions for which we have recorded a valuation allowance </font><font style="display: inline;">of $</font><font style="display: inline;">25.9</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million</font><font style="display: inline;"> against these deferred tax assets because we do not believe that it is more likely than not that we will be able to realize these deferred tax assets. The significant components of the deferred tax assets for which a valuation allowance has been applied consist of net operating losses in certain tax jurisdictions for which management believes there is not sufficient positive evidence that such net operating losses will be realized against future income and book expenses not deductible for tax purposes in the current year such as inventory impairment reserves, equity compensation and unrealized foreign exchange loss that would increase such net operating losses in the same jurisdictions. These temporary differences are amounts which arose in jurisdictions where (i)&nbsp;current losses exist, (ii)&nbsp;such losses are in excess of any loss carryback potential, (iii)&nbsp;no tax planning strategies exist with which to overcome such losses and (iv)&nbsp;no profits are projected for the following year. For these reasons it is determined that it is more likely than not that these deferred tax assets will not be realized and a valuation allowance has been provided with respect to these deferred tax assets.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">At Decembe</font><font style="display: inline;">r&nbsp;31, 2012, we</font><font style="display: inline;"> had U.S. federal net op</font><font style="display: inline;">erating loss carryforwards of $</font><font style="display: inline;">0.7</font><font style="display: inline;"> &nbsp;m</font><font style="display: inline;">illion, state net operating loss carryforwards of $</font><font style="display: inline;">89.6</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, charitable contribution carryforwards of $</font><font style="display: inline;">23.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and foreign tax credits</font><font style="display: inline;"> of</font><font style="display: inline;"> &nbsp;$</font><font style="display: inline;">5.0</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million</font><font style="display: inline;"> which will expire at various dates b</font><font style="display: inline;">etween 2014 and 2031. We</font><font style="display: inline;"> do not believe that it is more likely than not that the benefit from certain state net operating losses will be realized. Consequently, we have a valuation allowanc</font><font style="display: inline;">e of $</font><font style="display: inline;">9.1</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;mi</font><font style="display: inline;">llion on the deferred tax assets relating to these state net operating loss carryf</font><font style="display: inline;">orwards and charitable contribution carryforwards.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">At Decembe</font><font style="display: inline;">r&nbsp;31, 2012, w</font><font style="display: inline;">e have a foreign deferred tax a</font><font style="display: inline;">sset of $</font><font style="display: inline;">11.4</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million</font><font style="display: inline;"> reflecting the benef</font><font style="display: inline;">it of $</font><font style="display: inline;">43.8</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;milli</font><font style="display: inline;">on in foreign net operating loss carryforwards, some of which have an indefinite life.&nbsp;&nbsp;We do not believe it is more likely than not that the benefit from c</font><font style="display: inline;">ertain foreign net operating loss carryforwards will be realized. Consequently, we have provided a valuation allowance of $</font><font style="display: inline;">7.7</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million on the</font><font style="display: inline;"> deferred tax assets relating to these foreign net operating loss carryforwards.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">We had approx</font><font style="display: inline;">imately $</font><font style="display: inline;">36.7</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million in net d</font><font style="display: inline;">eferred tax assets at December&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">31, 2012. A</font><font style="display: inline;">pproxima</font><font style="display: inline;">tely $</font><font style="display: inline;">11.9</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;millio</font><font style="display: inline;">n of the net deferred tax assets were located in foreign jurisdictions for which a sufficient history and expected future profits indicated that it is more likely than not that such deferred tax assets will be realized. Pre-tax profit of appro</font><font style="display: inline;">ximately $</font><font style="display: inline;">47.4</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million is</font><font style="display: inline;"> required to realize the net deferred tax assets.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">At December&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">31, 2012, a</font><font style="display: inline;">ppro</font><font style="display: inline;">ximately $</font><font style="display: inline;">3.8</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million of net deferre</font><font style="display: inline;">d tax assets consists of deferred tax assets related to estimated liabilities for uncertain tax positions that would be realized if such liabilities are actually incurred. The deferred tax assets represent primarily the reduction in tax expense that would occur upon an increase of intercompany royalty expense by various taxing authorities. Approximatel</font><font style="display: inline;">y $</font><font style="display: inline;">15.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> million of taxa</font><font style="display: inline;">ble income would have to be recognized to realize these deferred tax assets.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">As a result of certain accounting realization requirements, the table of deferred tax assets and liabilities shown above does not include certain deferred tax ass</font><font style="display: inline;">ets at December&nbsp;31, 2012 tha</font><font style="display: inline;">t arose directly from tax deductions related to equity compensation in excess of compensation recognized for financial reporting. Equity will b</font><font style="display: inline;">e increased by $</font><font style="display: inline;">1</font><font style="display: inline;">1.8</font><font style="display: inline;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;"> if and when such deferred tax assets are ultimately realized. We use ASC 740 ordering for purposes of determining when excess tax benefits have been realized.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The following table sets forth a reconciliation of the beginning and ending amount of unrecognized tax benefits during the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010</font><font style="display: inline;">.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: <font style="display: inline;">Unrecognized tax benefits </font><font style="display: inline;">of $</font><font style="display: inline;">31.9</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, $</font><font style="display: inline;">44.5</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, and $</font><font style="display: inline;">33.0</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million at </font><font style="display: inline;">Dec</font><font style="display: inline;">ember 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010</font><font style="display: inline;">, respectively, if recognized, would reduce our annual effective tax rate.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Interest and penalties related to income tax liabilities are included in income tax expense in the consolidated statement of operations. As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010</font><font style="display: inline;">, we recorded appro</font><font style="display: inline;">ximately $</font><font style="display: inline;">0.6</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, $</font><font style="display: inline;">1.0</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, and $</font><font style="display: inline;">0.1</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, respectively</font><font style="display: inline;">, of penalties and interest which resulted in a cumulative accrued balance of penalties a</font><font style="display: inline;">nd interest of $</font><font style="display: inline;">4.4</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, </font><font style="display: inline;">3.9</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, and $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.9</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million at </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010</font><font style="display: inline;">, respec</font><font style="display: inline;">tively.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Unrecognized tax benefits consist primarily of tax positions related to intercompany transfer pricing in multiple international jurisdictions. The gross increase for tax positions in current and prior periods in 2012 </font><font style="display: inline;">of $</font><font style="display: inline;">3.9</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million primarily includes specific transfer pricing exposures in various jurisdictions. We </font><font style="display: inline;">do not expect any significant changes in unrecognized tax benefits in the next twelve months.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The following table sets forth the remaining tax years subject to examination for the major jurisdictions where we conduct business as of 14205000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Income Taxes</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Income taxes are accounted for using the asset and liability method which requires the recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities for the expected future tax consequences of temporary differences between the carrying amounts and the tax basis of other assets and liabilities. We provide for income taxes at the current and future enacted tax rates and laws applicable in each taxing jurisdiction. We use a two-step approach for recognizing and measuring tax benefits taken or expected to be taken in a tax return and disclosures regarding uncertainties in income tax positions. We recognize interest and penalties related to income tax matters in income tax expense in the consolidated statement of operations. See Note&nbsp;11&#x2014;Income Taxes for further discussion.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 12689000 30314000 99000 13165000 23278000 9475000 -228000 1097000 4907000 27908000 13328000 35493000 20344000 19922000 8016000 -2230000 17598000 25490000 -38000 343000 2154000 2113563 1663484 1017311 111000 113000 48641000 59931000 48641000 59931000 657000 853000 837000 639000 843000 619000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">2. nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>164,804&nbsp; </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:03.22%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>129,627&nbsp; </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">During the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010</font><font style="display: inline;">, we donated certain inventory items to charitable organizations consisting primarily of end of life units. The contributions made were expensed at their fair value o</font><font style="display: inline;">f $</font><font style="display: inline;">1.7</font><font style="display: inline;"> million,</font><font style="display: inline;"> &nbsp;$</font><font style="display: inline;">2.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">0.8</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, r</font><font style="display: inline;">espectively. Also during the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010</font><font style="display: inline;">, we recognized a gai</font><font style="display: inline;">n of $</font><font style="display: inline;">0.6</font><font style="display: inline;"> million,</font><font style="display: inline;"> &nbsp;$</font><font style="display: inline;">0.7</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">0.2</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, re</font><font style="display: inline;">spectively, and a net reduction of inventory of </font><font style="display: inline;">$</font><font style="display: inline;">1.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million,</font><font style="display: inline;"> &nbsp;$</font><font style="display: inline;">1.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">0.6</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, re</font><font style="display: inline;">spectively, as the fair value of the inventory contributed exceeded its carrying amount.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 124203000 155833000 129627000 164804000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Inventory Valuation</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market. Inventory cost is determined using the moving average cost method. At least annually, we evaluate our inventory for possible impairment using standard categories to classify inventory based on the degree to which we believe that the products may need to be discounted below cost to sell within a reasonable period. We base inventory fair value on several subjective assumptions including estimated future demand and market conditions, as well as other observable factors such as current sell-through of our products, recent changes in demand for our products, global and regional economic conditions, historical experience selling through liquidation and price discounted channels and the amount of inventory on hand. If the estimated inventory fair value is less than its carrying value, the carrying value is adjusted to market value and the resulting impairment charge is recorded in cost of sales on the consolidated statements of oper</font><font style="display: inline;">ations. S</font><font style="display: inline;">ee Note&nbsp;2&#x2014;Inventories for further discussi</font><font style="display: inline;">on related to inventorie</font><font style="display: inline;">s.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 5133000 8060000 291000 911000 65338000 88653000 6000000 6400000 203673000 212238000 695453000 829638000 155303000 157938000 422000 5900000 6582000 4596000 2013000 1280000 1666000 1623000 68005000 68713000 5245000 8917000 -16625000 -42078000 -41664000 -65943000 104274000 142376000 128356000 67726000 67726000 21504000 112788000 112788000 55506000 30207000 5571000 28346000 131343000 131343000 61524000 45080000 -3607000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Recently Adopted Accounting </font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Pronouncement</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">s</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In May&nbsp;2011, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#x201C;FASB&#x201D;) issued Accounting Standards Update (&#x201C;ASU&#x201D;) No.&nbsp;2011-04, &#x201C;Amendments to Achieve Common Fair Value Measurement and Disclosure Requirements in U.S. GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards (&#x201C;IFRS&#x201D;).&#x201D; This pronouncement was issued to provide a consistent definition of fair value and ensure that the fair value measurement and disclosure requirements are similar between U.S. GAAP and IFRS. ASU 2011-04 changes certain fair value measurement principles and enhances the disclosure requirements particularly for level 3 fair value measurements. This pronouncement is effective for reporting periods beginning on or after December&nbsp;15, 2011. </font><font style="display: inline;">The adoption of ASU 2011-04 did not </font><font style="display: inline;">have a </font><font style="display: inline;">material</font><font style="display: inline;"> impact to our consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In June&nbsp;2011, the FASB issued ASU No.&nbsp;2011-05, &#x201C;Presentation of Comprehensive Income.&#x201D; ASU 2011-05 eliminates the option to report other comprehensive income and its components in the statement of changes in stockholders&#x2019; equity and requires an entity to present the total of comprehensive income, the components of net income and the components of other comprehensive income either in a single continuous statement or in two separate but consecutive statements. This pronouncement </font><font style="display: inline;">was</font><font style="display: inline;"> effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December&nbsp;15,&nbsp;2011. Due to the fact that ASU 2011-05 concerns presentation and disclosure only, </font><font style="display: inline;">our adoption of this standard in 2012</font><font style="display: inline;"> did not have a</font><font style="display: inline;"> material</font><font style="display: inline;"> impact on the consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In September 2011, the </font><font style="display: inline;">FASB</font><font style="display: inline;"> issued A</font><font style="display: inline;">SU</font><font style="display: inline;"> No. 2011-08, &#x201C;Testing Goodwill for Impairment.&#x201D; This pronouncement was issued to allow companies to assess qualitative factors to determine if it is more-likely-than-not that goodwill might be impaired and whether it is necessary to perform the two-step goodwill impairment test required under current accounting s</font><font style="display: inline;">tandards. This pronouncement wa</font><font style="display: inline;">s effective for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2011. The adoption of ASU 2011-08 did not have a </font><font style="display: inline;">material</font><font style="display: inline;"> impact to our consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In December 2011, the F</font><font style="display: inline;">ASB issued ASU No. 2011-12, &#x201C;Deferral of the Effective Date for Amendments to the Presentation</font><font style="display: inline;"> of Reclassifications of Items o</font><font style="display: inline;">ut of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income in Accounting Standards Update No. 2011-05.&#x201D; This pronouncement was issued due to Stakeholders raising concerns that the new presentation requirements about reclassifications of items out of accumulated other comprehensive income would be difficult for preparers and may add unnecessary complexity to financial statements and </font><font style="display: inline;">was issued with the intent for c</font><font style="display: inline;">ompanies to defer only those changes in ASU 2011-05 that relate to the presentation of reclassification adjustments until the Board is able to reconsider certain paragraphs. </font><font style="display: inline;">This pronouncement wa</font><font style="display: inline;">s effective for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2011. The adoption of ASU 2011-</font><font style="display: inline;">12</font><font style="display: inline;"> did not have a </font><font style="display: inline;">material</font><font style="display: inline;"> impact to our consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In July 2012, the FASB issued ASU No. 2012-02, &#x201C;Testing Indefinite-Lived Intangible Assets for Impairment.&#x201D; This pronouncement was issued to simplify how an entity tests indefinite-lived intangible assets other than goodwill for impairment by providing entities with an option to perform a qualitative assessment to determine whether further impairment testing is necessary. This pronouncement is effective for reporting periods beginning after September 15, 2012. The adoption of ASU 2012-02 did not have a </font><font style="display: inline;">material</font><font style="display: inline;"> impact to our consolidated financial position, results of operations or style="float:left"></div>53,737&nbsp; </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="middle" style="width:68.92%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 style="float:left"></div>44,189&nbsp; </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="middle" style="width:68.92%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:21.24%;border-top:1pt style="float:left"></div>36,770&nbsp; </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="middle" style="width:68.92%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt 6pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Thereafter </font></p> </td> <td valign="middle" style="width:04.92%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt 6pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="middle" style="width:04.92%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 Roman;font-size: 10pt"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:21.24%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #FFFFFF;;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>132,390&nbsp; </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="middle" style="width:68.92%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt 6pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Total minimum lease payments</font><sup style="display: inline;">(1)</sup><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font></p> </td> <td valign="middle" style="width:04.92%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt
