style="width:04.92%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:2pt double #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt;text-align:center;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">$</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:21.24%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:2pt double #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>410,904&nbsp; </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 9847000 13639000 16519000 57989000 68675000 84671000 67283000 81741000 100571000 553000 573000 619000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;text-align:center;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p><p style="page-break-after:always">&nbsp;</p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;text-align:center;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"><font style="display: inline;"></font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">CROCS,&nbsp;INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;text-align:center;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">1. ORGANIZATION &amp; SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Organization</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Crocs,&nbsp;Inc. and its subsidiaries (collectively the &#x201C;Company,&#x201D; &#x201C;we,&#x201D; &#x201C;our&#x201D; or &#x201C;us&#x201D;) are engaged in the design, development, manufacturing, marketing and distribution of consumer products, primarily casual and athletic shoes and shoe charms, manufactured from specialty resins referred to as Croslite. Our wholly owned subsidiaries include, among others, EXO Italia (&#x201C;EXO&#x201D;), which designs and develops EVA (Ethylene Vinyl Acetate) based finished products, primarily for the footwear industry; Jibbitz,&nbsp;LLC (&#x201C;Jibbitz&#x201D;), a unique accessory brand with colorful snap-on charms specifically suited for our shoes; and Ocean Minded,&nbsp;Inc. (&#x201C;Ocean Minded&#x201D;), which designs, manufactures, markets and distributes high quality leather and EVA based sandals primarily for the beach, adventure and action sports markets.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Basis of Consolidation and Variable Interest Entities</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of our wholly-owned and majority-owned subsidiaries as well as variable interest entities (&#x201C;VIE&#x201D;) for which we are the primary beneficiary after the elimination of intercompany accounts and transactions. The primary beneficiary of a VIE is the entity that has (i) the power to direct the activities of the VIE that most significantly impact the VIE&#x2019;s economic performance and (ii) the obligation to absorb losses of the VIE that could potentially be significant to the VIE or the right to receive benefits from the VIE that could potentially be significant to the VIE.</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In 2007, we established a relationship with Shanghai Shengyiguan Trade,&nbsp;Ltd Co (&#x201C;ST&#x201D;) for the purpose of serving as a distributor of our products in </font><font style="display: inline;">the People&#x2019;s Republic of China. We had previously determined that ST was a VIE for which we were the primary beneficiary and consequently it was consolidated as if a wholly-owned subsidiary. On March 15, 2012, the Company exercised an Equity Option Agreement that we had in place with ST and became the sole owner of ST.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In April 2011, we and an unrelated third party formed Crocs Gulf, LLC (&#x201C;Crocs Gulf&#x201D;) for the purpose of selling our products in the United Arab Emirates. We have determined that Crocs Gulf is also a VIE for which we are the primary beneficiary due our variable interest in Crocs Gulf&#x2019;s equity and because we currently control all of the VIE&#x2019;s business activities and will absorb all of its expected residual returns and expected losses. All voting and dividend rights have been assigned to us. As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012 and 2011</font><font style="display: inline;">, the consolidated financial statements included $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.5</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">1.4</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million in total assets of Crocs Gulf, respectively, which primarily consisted of cash and cash equivalents, inventory and property and equipment. The to</font><font style="display: inline;">tal assets as of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012</font><font style="display: inline;"> were partially offset </font><font style="display: inline;">by $</font><font style="display: inline;">0.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> &nbsp;m</font><font style="display: inline;">illion in total liabilities</font><font style="display: inline;">, which primarily consisted of accou</font><font style="display: inline;">nts payable and accrued expenses, excluding liabilities related to the support provided by us. The total assets as of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2011 </font><font style="display: inline;">were partially offse</font><font style="display: inline;">t by an immaterial amount of</font><font style="display: inline;"> total liabilities primarily consisting of accrued expenses, excluding intercompany payables.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Noncontrolling Interests</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;</font><font style="display: inline;">As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012, all</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">of our subsidiaries were, in substance, wholly owned.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Concentrations of Risk</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;We are exposed to concentrations of risks in the following categories. </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">Cash and cash equivalents</font><font style="display: inline;"> - Our cash and cash equivalents are maintained in several different financial institutions in amounts that typically exceed U.S. federally insured limits or in financial institutions in international jurisdictions where insurance is not provided and restrictions may exist.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">As we are a global business, we have cash and cash equivalent balances which are located in various countries and are denominated in various currencies. </font><font style="display: inline;">Most of the cash balances held outside of the U.S. could be repatriated to the U.S., but under current law, would be subject to U.S. federal and state income taxes less applicable foreign tax credits. In some countries, repatriation of certain foreign balances is restricted by local laws and could have adverse tax consequences if we were to move the cash to another country. Certain countries, including China, have monetary laws which may limit our ability to utilize cash resources in those countries for operations in other countries. These limitations may affect our ability to fully utilize our cash and cash equivalent resources for needs in the U.S. or other countries and could adversely affect our liquidity. As of December 31, 2012, w</font><font style="display: inline;">e held $</font><font style="display: inline;">2</font><font style="display: inline;">72.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> &nbsp;m</font><font style="display: inline;">illion of our total $</font><font style="display: inline;">29</font><font style="display: inline;">4.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million in cash in international locations. This cash is primarily used for the ongoing operations of the business in the locations in which the cash is held. Of the </font><font style="display: inline;">$</font><font style="display: inline;">2</font><font style="display: inline;">72.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million h</font><font style="display: inline;">eld in international locations, </font><font style="display: inline;">$</font><font style="display: inline;">38.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> million could pot</font><font style="display: inline;">entially be restricted, as described above.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">Accounts receivable</font><font style="display: inline;"> - We have not experienced any significant losses in such accounts and believe we are not exposed to significant credit risk. We consider any concentration of credit risk related to accounts receivable to be mitigated by our credit policy, the insignificance of outstanding balances owed by each individual customer at any point in time and the geographic dispersion of our customers.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">Manufacturing sources</font><font style="display: inline;"> - We rely on a limited source of internal and external manufacturers. Establishing a replacement source could require significant additional time and expense.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">Suppliers of certain raw materials</font><font style="display: inline;"> - We source the elastomer resins that constitute the primary raw materials used in compounding Croslite, which we use to produce our footwear products, from multiple suppliers. If the suppliers we rely on for elastomer resins were to cease production of these materials, we may not be able to obtain suitable substitute materials in time to avoid interruption of our production cycle, if at all. We may also have to pay materially higher prices in the future for the elastomer resins or any substitute materials we use, which would increase our production costs and could have a materially adverse impact on our margins and results of operations.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Reclassifications</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Certain prior period amounts presented in the consolidated financial statements have been reclassified to conform to current period presentation</font><font style="display: inline;"> as follows</font><font style="display: inline;">.</font><font style="display: inline;"> We reclassified &#x2018;Foreign currency transaction (gains) losses, net&#x2019; line item from &#x2018;Income from operations&#x2019; to &#x2018;Income before income taxes&#x2019; in the Consolidated Statements of </font><font style="display: inline;">Operations</font><font style="display: inline;">. We also reclassified (gains) losses on our derivative contracts from &#x2018;Other (income) expense&#x2019; to the &#x2018;Foreign currency transactions (gains) losses, net&#x2019; line item. As a result of these reclassifications, &#x2018;Income from operation</font><font style="display: inline;">s&#x2019; </font><font style="display: inline;">decreased $</font><font style="display: inline;">5.4</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.9</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, res</font><font style="display: inline;">pectively, for</font><font style="display: inline;"> the year</font><font style="display: inline;">s</font><font style="display: inline;"> ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2011 and 2010</font><font style="display: inline;">.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Management Estimates</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;The preparation of financial statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America (&#x201C;GAAP&#x201D;) requires management to make estimates, judgments and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting period. Management believes that the estimates, judgments and assumptions made when accounting for items and matters such as, but not limited to, the allowance for doubtful accounts, sales returns, impairment assessments and charges, recoverability of assets (including deferred tax assets), uncertain tax positions, share-based compensation expense, the assessment of lower of cost or market on inventory, useful lives assigned to long-lived assets, depreciation and provisions for contingencies are reasonable based on information available at the time they are made. Management also makes estimates in the assessments of potential losses in relation to tax </font><font style="display: inline;">and customs </font><font style="display: inline;">matters and threatened or pending legal proceedings (see Note&nbsp;15&#x2014;Legal Proceedings). Actual results could materially differ from these estimates. For matters not related to income taxes, if a loss is considered probable and the amount can be reasonably estimated, we recognize an expense for the estimated loss. If there is the potential to recover a portion of the estimated loss from a third party, we make a separate assessment of recoverability and reduce the estimated loss if recovery is deemed probable.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Fair Value</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Fair value is the price that would be received from the sale of an asset or transfer of a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. When determining the fair value measurements for assets and liabilities which are required to be recorded at fair value, we consider the principal or most advantageous market in which a hypothetical sale or transfer would take place and consider assumptions that market participants would use when pricing the asset or liability, such as inherent risk, transfer restrictions, and risk of non-performance.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The fair value hierarchy is made up of three levels of inputs which may be used to measure fair value: </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Level&nbsp;1&#x2014;observable inputs such as quoted prices for identical instruments in active markets; </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Level&nbsp;2&#x2014;observable inputs such as quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active and model derived valuations in which all significant inputs are observable in active markets; and </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Level&nbsp;3&#x2014;unobservable inputs for which there is little or no market data and which require us to develop our own assumptions. We categorize fair value measurements within the fair value hierarchy based upon the lowest level of the most significant inputs used to </font><font style="display: inline;">determine such fair value measurement.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt; font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Cash equivalents primarily include time deposits and certificates of deposit with original maturities of three months or less. Time deposits and certificates of deposit included in cash equivalents are valued at amortized cost, which approximates fair value. These investments have been classified as a Level 1 measurement.</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Derivative financial instruments are required to be recorded at their fair value, on a recurring basis. The fair values of our derivative instruments are determined using a discounted cash flow valuation model. The significant inputs used in the model are readily available in public markets or can be derived from observable market transactions, and therefore, have been classified as Level&nbsp;2. These inputs include the applicable exchange rates and forward rates, and discount rates based on the prevailing LIBOR deposit rates.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Our other financial instruments are not required to be carried at fair value on a recurring basis. The carrying value of these financial instruments, including cash equivalents, accounts receivable, accounts payable and accrued liabilities, approximates fair value due to their short maturities. Based on borrowing rates currently available to us, with similar terms, the carrying values of capital lease obligations and the line of credit approximate their fair values.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Inventories and long-lived assets such as property and equipment and intangible assets are also not required to be carried at fair value on a recurring basis. For a discussion of inventory estimated fair value see &#x201C;Inventory Valuation&#x201D; below. However, when determining impairment losses, the fair values of property and equipment and intangibles must be determined. For such determination, we </font><font style="display: inline;">geneally </font><font style="display: inline;">use either an income approach with inputs that are mainly unobservable, such as expected future cash flows, or a market approach using observable inputs such as replacement cost or third party appraisals, as appropriate. Estimated future cash flows are based on management&#x2019;s operating budgets and forecasts which take into consideration both observable and unobservable inputs including growth rates, pricing, new markets and other factors expected to affect the business, as well as management&#x2019;s forecasts for inventory, receivables, capital spending, and other cash needs.</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">See Note&nbsp;6</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;</font><font style="display: inline;">Fair Value Measurements</font><font style="display: inline;"> for further discussion related to </font><font style="display: inline;">fair value measurements.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Cash and Cash Equivalents</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Cash and cash equivalents represent cash and short-term, highly liquid investments with maturities of three months or less at the date of purchase. We consider receivables from credit card companies to be cash equivalents, if expected to be received within five days. </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Accounts Receivable</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Accounts receivable represent amounts due from customers. Accounts receivable are recorded at invoiced amounts, net of reserves and allowances, are not collateralized and do not bear interest. We use our best estimate to determine the required allowance for doubtful accounts based on a variety of factors, including the length of time receivables are past due, economic trends and conditions affecting our customer base, significant one-time events and historical non-collection experience. Specific provisions are recorded for individual receivables when we become aware of a customer&#x2019;s inability to meet its financial obligations.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Inventory Valuation</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market. Inventory cost is determined using the moving average cost method. At least annually, we evaluate our inventory for possible impairment using standard categories to classify inventory based on the degree to which we believe that the products may need to be discounted below cost to sell within a reasonable period. We base inventory fair value on several subjective assumptions including estimated future demand and market conditions, as well as other observable factors such as current sell-through of our products, recent changes in demand for our products, global and regional economic conditions, historical experience selling through liquidation and price discounted channels and the amount of inventory on hand. If the estimated inventory fair value is less than its carrying value, the carrying value is adjusted to market value and the resulting impairment charge is recorded in cost of sales on the consolidated statements of oper</font><font style="display: inline;">ations. S</font><font style="display: inline;">ee Note&nbsp;2&#x2014;Inventories for further discussi</font><font style="display: inline;">on related to inventorie</font><font style="display: inline;">s.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Property and Equipment</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Depreciation of property, equipment, furniture and fixtures is computed using the straight-line method based on estimated useful lives ranging from two to five years. Leasehold improvements are amortized on the straight-line basis over their estimated economic useful lives or the lease term, whichever is shorter. Depreciation of manufacturing assets such as molds and tooling is included in cost of sales on the consolidated statements of operations. Depreciation related to corporate, non-product and non-manufacturing assets is included in selling, general and administrative expenses on the consolidated statements of operations.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Impairment of Long-Lived Assets</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Long-lived assets to be held and used are evaluated for impairment when events or circumstances indicate the carrying value of a long-lived asset may not be fully recoverable. Events that may indicate the impairment of a long-lived asset (or asset group, as defined below) include; (i)&nbsp;a significant decrease in its market price, (ii)&nbsp;a significant adverse change in the extent or manner in which it is being used or in its physical condition, (iii)&nbsp;a significant adverse change in legal factors or business climate that could affect its value, including an adverse action or assessment by a regulator, (iv)&nbsp;an accumulation of costs significantly in excess of the amount originally expected for its acquisition or construction, (v)&nbsp;its current period operating or cash flow losses combined with historical operating or cash flow losses or a forecast of its cash flows demonstrate continuing losses associated with its use, and (vi)&nbsp;a current expectation that, more likely than not, it will be sold or otherwise disposed of significantly before the end of its previously estimated useful life. If such facts indicate a potential impairment of a long-lived asset (or asset group), we assess the recoverability by determining if its carrying value exceeds the sum of its projected undiscounted cash flows from its use and eventual disposition over its remaining economic life. If the asset is not supported on an undiscounted cash flow basis, the amount of impairment is measured as the difference between its carrying value and its fair value. Assets held for sale are reported at the lower of the carrying amount or fair value less costs to sell. Assets to be abandoned or from which no further benefit is expected are written down to zero at the time that the determination is made and the assets are removed entirely from service.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">An asset group is the lowest level of assets and liabilities for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the cash flows of other assets and liabilities.&nbsp; </font><font style="display: inline;">For assets involved in our retail business our asset group is at the retail store level.</font><font style="display: inline;"> See Note 3 &#x2013; Property and Equipment for a discussion of impairment losses recorded during the periods presented.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt; font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Intangible Assets</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&#x2014;Intangible assets that are determined to have finite lives are amortized over their useful lives on a straight-line basis. Customer relationships are amortized on a straight-line basis or an accelerated basis. Indefinite lived intangible assets, such as trade names, are not amortized and are evaluated for impairment at least annually and when circumstances imply possible impairment. </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Amortization of manufacturing intangible assets is included in cost of sales on the consolidated statements of operations. Amortization related to corporate, non-product and non-manufacturing assets such as our global information systems is included in selling, general and administrative expenses on the consolidated statements of operations. The following table sets forth our definite lived intangible assets and the periods over which they are amortized.</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" align="center" style="border-collapse:collapse;width: 75.00%;margin-left:0pt;"> <tr> <td valign="bottom" style="width:215.00pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 1pt;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:8pt;">Intangible Asset Class</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:195.40pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 1pt;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000 ;text-align:center;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:8pt;">Weighted Average Amortization Period</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top" style="width:215.00pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 10pt;text-indent: -10pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:-10pt; width:192.65pt; overflow: hidden; white-space: nowrap;"><font style="display: inline;">Patents</font>.............................................................................</font><font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:0pt; width:-1pt;text-align:right"><font style="display: inline;"></font></font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:195.40pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">10&nbsp;years</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top" style="width:215.00pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 10pt;text-indent: -10pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:-10pt; width:192.65pt; overflow: hidden; white-space: nowrap;"><font style="display: inline;">Customer relationships</font>.............................................</font><font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:0pt; width:-1pt;text-align:right"><font style="display: inline;"></font></font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:195.40pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Estimated customer life</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top" style="width:215.00pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 10pt;text-indent: -10pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:-10pt; width:192.65pt; overflow: hidden; white-space: nowrap;"><font style="display: inline;">Core technology</font>...........................................................</font><font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:0pt; width:-1pt;text-align:right"><font style="display: inline;"></font></font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:195.40pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">5&nbsp;years</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top" style="width:215.00pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 10pt;text-indent: -10pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:-10pt; width:192.65pt; overflow: hidden; white-space: nowrap;"><font style="display: inline;">Non-competition agreement</font>....................................</font><font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:0pt; width:-1pt;text-align:right"><font style="display: inline;"></font></font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:195.40pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Contractual term</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top" style="width:215.00pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 10pt;text-indent: -10pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:-10pt; width:192.65pt; overflow: hidden; white-space: nowrap;"><font style="display: inline;">Capitalized software</font>...................................................</font><font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:0pt; width:-1pt;text-align:right"><font style="display: inline;"></font></font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:195.40pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Shorter of 7&nbsp;years or useful life</font></p> </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 12pt 31.5pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">Capitalized Software</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;We capitalize certain internal and external software acquisition and development costs, including the costs of employees and contractors devoting time to the software development projects and external direct costs for materials and services. Initial costs associated with internally-developed-and-used software are expensed until it is determined that the project has reached the application development stage. Once in its development stage, subsequent additions, modifications or upgrades to an internal-use software project are capitalized to the extent that they add functionality. Software maintenance and training costs are expensed in the period in which they are incurred. Capitalized software primarily consists of our enterprise resource system software, warehouse management software and point of sale software. At least annually, we consider the potential impairment of capitalized software by assessing the substantive service potential of the software, changes, if any, in the extent or manner in which the software is used or is expected to be used, and the actual cost of software development or modification compared to expected cost. See Note&nbsp;4&#x2014;Goodwill and Intangible Assets for further discussion.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 12pt 31.5pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">Impairment of Intangible Assets</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Intangible assets with indefinite lives are evaluated for impairment when events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be fully recoverable and at least annually. Intangible assets that are determined to have definite lives are amortized over their useful lives and are evaluated for impairment only when events or circumstances indicate a carrying value may not be fully recoverable. Recoverability is based on the estimated future undiscounted cash flows of the asset. If the asset is not supported on an undiscounted cash flow basis, the amount of impairment is measured as the difference between its carrying value and its fair value.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Goodwill</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;</font><font style="display: inline;">Goodwill</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;"> represents the excess purchase price paid over the fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed in acquisitions</font><font style="display: inline;">. Goodwill is</font><font style="display: inline;"> considered an indefinite lived asset and therefore is not amortized.&nbsp; </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">The Company assesses goodwill for impairment annually on the last day of the fourth quarter, or more frequently if events and circumstances indicate impairment may have occurred. If the carrying value of goodwill exceeds its implied fair value, the Company records an impairment loss equal to the difference. See </font><font style="display: inline;">Note&nbsp;4</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;</font><font style="display: inline;">Goodwill</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;"> and Intangible Assets for discussion of goodwill balances. There was no impairment of goodwill for the year ended </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">December 31, 2012. We did not have any goodwill for the year ended </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">December 31, 2011.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Earnings per Share</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Basic and diluted earnings (loss) per common share (&#x201C;EPS&#x201D;) is presented using the two-class method, which is an earnings allocation formula that determines earnings per share for common stock and any participating securities according to dividend rights and participation rights in undistributed earnings. Under the two-class method, EPS is computed by dividing the sum of distributed and undistributed earnings (loss) attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding during the period. A participating security is an unvested share-based payment award containing non-forfeitable rights to dividends and must be included in the computation of earnings per share pursuant to the two-class method. Shares of the Company&#x2019;s non-vested restricted stock awards are considered participating securities. Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution from securities that could share in the earnings of the Company. Anti-dilutive securities are excluded from diluted EPS. See Note&nbsp;12&#x2014;Earnings per Share for further discussion.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Recognition of Revenues</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Revenues are recognized when the customer takes title and assumes risk of loss, collection of related receivables is probable, persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, and the sales price is fixed or determinable. Title passes on shipment or on receipt by the customer depending on the country in which the sale occurs and the agreement terms with the customer. Allowances for estimated returns and discounts are recognized when the related revenue is earned.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Shipping and Handling Costs and Fees</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Shipping and handling costs are expensed as incurred and included in cost of sales. Shipping and handling fees billed to customers are included in revenues.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Share-based Compensation</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;We have s</font><font style="display: inline;">hare-based compensation plans in</font><font style="display: inline;"> which certain officers, employees and members of the Board of Directors are participants and may be granted stock options, restricted stock and stock performance awards. Awards granted under these plans are fair valued and amortized, net of estimated forfeitures, over the vesting period using the straight-line method. The fair value of stock options is calculated by using the Black Scholes option pricing model that requires estimates for expected volatility, expected dividends, the risk-free interest rate and the term of the option. If any of the assumptions used in the Black Scholes model or the anticipated number of shares to be awarded change significantly, share-based compensation expense may differ materially in the future from that recorded in the current period. See additional information related to share-based compensation in Note&nbsp;9&#x2014;Equity. Share-based compensation expense associated with our manufacturing and retail employees is included in cost of sales in the consolidated statements of operations. Share-based compensation expense associated with selling, marketing and administrative employees is included selling, general and administrative expenses on the consolidated statements of operations.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Defined contribution plans</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;</font><font style="display: inline;">We have a 401(k) plan known as the Crocs, Inc. 401(k) Plan (the &#x201C;Plan&#x201D;). The Plan is available to employees on our U.S. payroll and provides employees with tax deferred salary deductions and alternative investment options. The Plan does not provide employees with the option to invest in our common stock. Employees may contribute up to 75.0% of their salary, subject to certain limitations. We match employees&#x2019; contributions to the Plan up to a maximum of </font><font style="display: inline;">4.0</font><font style="display: inline;">% of eligible compensation. We expensed $</font><font style="display: inline;">5.8</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, $</font><font style="display: inline;">4.6</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">3.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million in the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010, respectively</font><font style="display: inline;">, for our employee match contributions to the Plan.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Advertising</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Advertising costs are expensed as incurred and production costs are generally expensed when the advertising is run. Total advertising, marketing and promotional costs reflected in selling, general, and administrative expenses on the consolidated statement of operations w</font><font style="display: inline;">e</font><font style="display: inline;">re $</font><font style="display: inline;">39.8</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, $</font><font style="display: inline;">39.8</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">44.1</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million for the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010</font><font style="display: inline;">, respectively.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Research and Development</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Research and development costs a</font><font style="display: inline;">re expensed as incurred. Research and development expenses amoun</font><font style="display: inline;">ted to $</font><font style="display: inline;">12.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, $</font><font style="display: inline;">10.8</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">7.8</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million for the</font><font style="display: inline;"> years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010</font><font style="display: inline;">, respectively, and are included in selling, general, and administrative expenses in the consolidated statement of operations.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Foreign Currency Translation and Foreign Currency Transactions</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Our </font><font style="display: inline;">reporting</font><font style="display: inline;"> currency is the U.S. dollar. Assets and liabilities of foreign operations denominated in local currencies are translated at the rate of exchange at the balance sheet date. Revenues and expenses are translated at the weighted average rate of exchange during the applicable period. Adjustments resulting from translating foreign functional currency financial statements into U.S. dollars are included in the foreign currency translation adjustment, a component of accumulated other comprehensive income in stockholders&#x2019; equity. </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Gains and losses generated by transactions denominated in </font><font style="display: inline;">currencies other than the local functional</font><font style="display: inline;"> currencies are reflected in the consolidated statement of operations in the period in which they occur and are primarily associated with payables and receivables arising from intercompany transa</font><font style="display: inline;">ctions.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Derivative Foreign Currency Contracts</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;We are directly and indirectly affected by fluctuations in foreign currency rates which may adversely impact our financial performance. To mitigate the potential impact of foreign currency exchange rate risk, we may employ derivative financial instruments including forward contracts and option contracts. Forward contracts are agreements to buy or sell a quantity of a currency at a predetermined future date and at a predetermined rate. An option contract is an agreement that conveys the purchaser the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell a quantity of a currency at a predetermined rate during a period or at a time in the future. These derivative financial instruments are viewed as risk management tools and are not used for trading or speculative purposes. We recognize derivative financial instruments as either assets or liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets and measure those instruments at fair value. Changes in the fair value of derivatives not designated or effective as hedges are recorded in </font><font style="display: inline;">&#x201C;foreign currency transaction (gains)/losses, net&#x201D; in the c</font><font style="display: inline;">onsolidated statements of operations. We had no derivative instruments that qualified for hedge accounting during any of the periods presented. See Note&nbsp;7&#x2014;Fair Value Measurements and Financial Instruments for further discussion.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Income Taxes</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Income taxes are accounted for using the asset and liability method which requires the recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities for the expected future tax consequences of temporary differences between the carrying amounts and the tax basis of other assets and liabilities. We provide for income taxes at the current and future enacted tax rates and laws applicable in each taxing jurisdiction. We use a two-step approach for recognizing and measuring tax benefits taken or expected to be taken in a tax return and disclosures regarding uncertainties in income tax positions. We recognize interest and penalties related to income tax matters in income tax expense in the consolidated statement of operations. See Note&nbsp;11&#x2014;Income Taxes for further discussion.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Taxes Assessed by Governmental Authorities</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Taxes assessed by governmental authorities that are directly imposed on a revenue transaction, including value added tax, are recorded on a net basis and are therefore excluded from sales.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">Application of Recent Accounting Pronouncements</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Recently Adopted Accounting </font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Pronouncement</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">s</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In May&nbsp;2011, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#x201C;FASB&#x201D;) issued Accounting Standards Update (&#x201C;ASU&#x201D;) No.&nbsp;2011-04, &#x201C;Amendments to Achieve Common Fair Value Measurement and Disclosure Requirements in U.S. GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards (&#x201C;IFRS&#x201D;).&#x201D; This pronouncement was issued to provide a consistent definition of fair value and ensure that the fair value measurement and disclosure requirements are similar between U.S. GAAP and IFRS. ASU 2011-04 changes certain fair value measurement principles and enhances the disclosure requirements particularly for level 3 fair value measurements. This pronouncement is effective for reporting periods beginning on or after December&nbsp;15, 2011. </font><font style="display: inline;">The adoption of ASU 2011-04 did not </font><font style="display: inline;">have a </font><font style="display: inline;">material</font><font style="display: inline;"> impact to our consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In June&nbsp;2011, the FASB issued ASU No.&nbsp;2011-05, &#x201C;Presentation of Comprehensive Income.&#x201D; ASU 2011-05 eliminates the option to report other comprehensive income and its components in the statement of changes in stockholders&#x2019; equity and requires an entity to present the total of comprehensive income, the components of net income and the components of other comprehensive income either in a single continuous statement or in two separate but consecutive statements. This pronouncement </font><font style="display: inline;">was</font><font style="display: inline;"> effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December&nbsp;15,&nbsp;2011. Due to the fact that ASU 2011-05 concerns presentation and disclosure only, </font><font style="display: inline;">our adoption of this standard in 2012</font><font style="display: inline;"> did not have a</font><font style="display: inline;"> material</font><font style="display: inline;"> impact on the consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In September 2011, the </font><font style="display: inline;">FASB</font><font style="display: inline;"> issued A</font><font style="display: inline;">SU</font><font style="display: inline;"> No. 2011-08, &#x201C;Testing Goodwill for Impairment.&#x201D; This pronouncement was issued to allow companies to assess qualitative factors to determine if it is more-likely-than-not that goodwill might be impaired and whether it is necessary to perform the two-step goodwill impairment test required under current accounting s</font><font style="display: inline;">tandards. This pronouncement wa</font><font style="display: inline;">s effective for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2011. The adoption of ASU 2011-08 did not have a </font><font style="display: inline;">material</font><font style="display: inline;"> impact to our consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In December 2011, the F</font><font style="display: inline;">ASB issued ASU No. 2011-12, &#x201C;Deferral of the Effective Date for Amendments to the Presentation</font><font style="display: inline;"> of Reclassifications of Items o</font><font style="display: inline;">ut of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income in Accounting Standards Update No. 2011-05.&#x201D; This pronouncement was issued due to Stakeholders raising concerns that the new presentation requirements about reclassifications of items out of accumulated other comprehensive income would be difficult for preparers and may add unnecessary complexity to financial statements and </font><font style="display: inline;">was issued with the intent for c</font><font style="display: inline;">ompanies to defer only those changes in ASU 2011-05 that relate to the presentation of reclassification adjustments until the Board is able to reconsider certain paragraphs. </font><font style="display: inline;">This pronouncement wa</font><font style="display: inline;">s effective for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2011. The adoption of ASU 2011-</font><font style="display: inline;">12</font><font style="display: inline;"> did not have a </font><font style="display: inline;">material</font><font style="display: inline;"> impact to our consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In July 2012, the FASB issued ASU No. 2012-02, &#x201C;Testing Indefinite-Lived Intangible Assets for Impairment.&#x201D; This pronouncement was issued to simplify how an entity tests indefinite-lived intangible assets other than goodwill for impairment by providing entities with an option to perform a qualitative assessment to determine whether further impairment testing is necessary. This pronouncement is effective for reporting periods beginning after September 15, 2012. The adoption of ASU 2012-02 did not have a </font><font style="display: inline;">material</font><font style="display: inline;"> impact to our consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Recently Issued Accounting Pronouncements</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In December 2011, the FASB issued ASU No. 2011-11, &#x201C;Disclosures about Offsetting Assets and Liabilities.&#x201D; This pronouncement was issued to enhance disclosure requirements surrounding the nature of an entity&#x2019;s right to offset and related arrangements associated with its financial instruments and derivative instruments. This new guidance requires companies to disclose both gross and net information about instruments and transactions eligible for offset in the statement of financial position and instruments and transactions subject to master netting arrangements. This pronouncement is effective for reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2013. We do not anticipate the adoption of ASU 2011-11 to have a material impact to the consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In January 20</font><font style="display: inline;">13, the FASB issued ASU No. 2013-01, &#x201C;Clarifying the Scope of Disclosures about Offsetting Assets and Liabilities</font><font style="display: inline;">.&#x201D; This pronoun</font><font style="display: inline;">cement was issued to address implementation issues about the scope of Accounting Standards Update No. 2011-11 and to clarify the scope of the offsetting disclosures and address any unintended consequences.</font><font style="display: inline;"> This pronouncement is effective for reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2013. We do not anticipate the adoption of ASU 2013-01 to have a material impact to the consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In February 2013, the FASB issued ASU No. 20</font><font style="display: inline;">13-02, </font><font style="display: inline;">'</font><font style="display: inline;">Reporting of Amounts Reclas</font><font style="display: inline;">sified Out of Accumulated Other </font><font style="display: inline;">Comprehensive Income</font><font style="display: inline;">.&#x201D; This pronouncement was</font><font style="display: inline;"> issued to improve the reporting of reclassifications out of accumulated other comprehensive </font><font style="display: inline;">income. The amendments in this u</font><font style="display: inline;">pdate seek to attain that objective by requiring an entity to report the effect of significant reclassifications out of accumulated other comprehensive income on the respective line items in net income if the amount being reclassified is required under U.S. </font><font style="display: inline;">GAAP</font><font style="display: inline;"> to be reclassified in its entirety to net income. For other amounts that are not required under U.S. GAAP to be reclassified in their entirety to net income in the same reporting period, an entity is required to cross-reference other disclosures required under U.S. GAAP that provide additional detail about those amounts. This would be the case when a portion of the amount reclassified out of accumulated other comprehensive income is reclassified to a balance sheet account (</font><font style="display: inline;">i.e.</font><font style="display: inline;"> inventory) instead of directly to income or expense in the same reporting period.</font><font style="display: inline;"> This pronouncement is effective prospectively for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2012. We do not anticipate the adoption of ASU 2013-02 to have a material impact to the consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 7995000 8835000 141000 32000 528000 495000 1000 713000 1410000 106000 591000 23410000 40239000 9048000 9048000 -16031000 -16031000 5525000 5525000 6705000 13361000 -1083000 -339000 -1392000 1001000 1578000 2711000 863000 1014000 645000 25074000 -421000 -421000 -490000 -490000 -493000 -493000 421000 490000 493000 5169000 13848000 13922000 21074000 5654000 31257000 27718000 39762000 0.001 0.001 5000000 5000000 20199000 24967000 2900000 5400000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Reclassifications</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Certain prior period amounts presented in the consolidated financial statements have been reclassified to conform to current period presentation</font><font style="display: inline;"> as follows</font><font style="display: inline;">.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 7191000 10914000 3706000 83100000 316595000 96086000 7369000 1274000 319000 2216000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">3. inline;">espectively, was recorded in cost of sales, with the remaining amounts recorded in selling, general and administrative expenses on the consolidated statements of operations.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">We periodically evaluate all of our long-lived assets for impairment when events or circumstances would indicate the carrying value of a long-lived as</font><font style="display: inline;">set may not be fully recoverable</font><font style="display: inline;">. During the year ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012</font><font style="display: inline;">, we rec</font><font style="display: inline;">orded $</font><font style="display: inline;">1.4</font><font style="display: inline;"> million in impairment charges related to certain underperforming dom</font><font style="display: inline;">estic stores in the Americas segment that were unlikely to generate sufficient cash fl</font><font style="display: inline;">ows to fully recover the carrying value of the stores' assets over the remaining economic life of those assets</font><font style="display: inline;">. &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">During the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2011 and 2010</font><font style="display: inline;">, we recorded </font><font style="display: inline;">$</font><font style="display: inline;">0.5</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">0.1</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, res</font><font style="display: inline;">pectively, in impairment charges which primarily related to obsolete molds which were previously depreciated to costs of sales.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 157441000 186959000 67684000 82241000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Property and Equipment</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Depreciation of property, equipment, furniture and fixtures is computed using the straight-line method based on estimated useful lives ranging from two to five years. Leasehold improvements are amortized on the straight-line basis over their estimated economic useful lives or the lease term, whichever is shorter. Depreciation of manufacturing assets such as molds and tooling is included in cost of sales on the consolidated statements of operations. Depreciation related to corporate, non-product and non-manufacturing assets is included in selling, general and administrative expenses on the consolidated statements of operations.</font> </p> size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Accounts Receivable</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Accounts receivable represent amounts due from customers. Accounts receivable are recorded at invoiced amounts, net of reserves and allowances, are not collateralized and do not bear interest. We use our best estimate to determine the required allowance for doubtful accounts based on a variety of factors, including the length of time receivables are past due, economic trends and conditions affecting our customer base, significant one-time events and historical non-collection experience. Specific provisions are recorded for individual receivables when we become aware of a customer&#x2019;s inability to meet its financial obligations.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 7800000 10800000 12000000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Research and Development</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Research and development costs a</font><font style="display: inline;">re expensed as incurred. nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>31,900&nbsp; </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:02.30%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Arial;">$</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:11.40%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:2pt double #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>44,537&nbsp; </td> <td valign="middle" style="width:02.30%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0.05pt;text-align:right;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:02.30%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:2pt double #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: style="width:11.40%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:2pt double #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>33,042&nbsp; </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">14. OPERATING SEGMENTS AND GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION</font> </p> <p style="margin:4.5pt 0pt 0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ; font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We have three reportable operating segments: Americas, Europe and Asia. We also have an &#x201C;Other businesses&#x201D; category which aggregates insignificant operating segments that do not meet the reportable threshold and represent manufacturing operations located in Mexico and Italy. The composition of our reportable operating segments is consistent with that used by our chief operating decision maker (&#x201C;CODM&#x201D;) to evaluate performance and allocate resources. </font> </p> <p style="margin:9pt 0pt 0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ; font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Each of our reportable operating segments derives its revenues from the sale of footwear, apparel and accessories to external customers. Revenues of the &#x201C;Other businesses&#x201D; category are primarily made up of intersegment sales which are eliminated when deriving total consolidated revenues. The remaining revenues for the &#x201C;Other businesses&#x201D; represent non-footwear product sales to external customers. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Segment assets consist of cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable and inventory.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ; font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Segment operating income is the primary measure used by our CODM to evaluate segment operating performance and to decide how to allocate resources to segments. Segment performance evaluation is based primarily on segment results without allocating corporate expenses, or indirect general, administrative and other expenses. Segment profits or losses of our reportable operating segments include adjustments to eliminate intersegment profit or losses on intersegment sales. </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">During the first quarter of 2012, we changed the internal reports used by our CODM to align the definition of our segment operating income with &#x201C;Income from operations.&#x201D; Previously, segment operating income excluded asset impairment charges and restructuring costs not included in cost of sales. Segment operating income also reflects the reclassification of &#x201C;Foreign currency transaction (gains) losses, net&#x201D; from &#x201C;Income from operations&#x201D; on the consolidated statements of income. </font><font style="display: inline;">See Note 1 &#x2013; Organization &amp; Summary of Significant Accounting Policies for </font><font style="display: inline;">further discussion. Segment information for all periods presented has been reclassified to reflect these changes.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p><p style="page-break-after:always">&nbsp;</p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"><font style="display: inline;"></font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The following tables set forth information related to our reportable operating business segments as of and for the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010</font><font style="display: inline;">.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table cellpadding="0" Awards granted under these plans are fair valued and amortized, net of estimated forfeitures, over the vesting period using the straight-line method. The fair value of stock options is calculated by using the Black Scholes option pricing model that requires estimates for expected volatility, expected dividends, the risk-free interest rate and the term of the option. If any of the assumptions used in the Black Scholes model or the anticipated number of shares to be awarded change significantly, share-based compensation expense may differ materially in the future from that recorded in the current period. See additional information related to share-based compensation in Note&nbsp;9&#x2014;Equity. Share-based compensation expense associated with our manufacturing and retail employees is included in cost of sales in the consolidated statements of operations. Share-based compensation expense associated with selling, marketing and administrative employees is included selling, general and administrative expenses on the consolidated statements of operations.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 85659000 565000 88066000 535000 89807000 499000 88663000 2384000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Shipping and Handling Costs and Fees</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Shipping and handling costs are expensed as incurred and included in cost of sales. EQUITY</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Equity Incentive Plans</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">On August&nbsp;15, 2005, </font><font style="display: inline;">we</font><font style="display: inline;"> adopted the 2005 Equity Incentive Plan (the &#x201C;2005 Plan&#x201D;), which permitted the issuance of up to </font><font style="display: inline;">14.0</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million common shares in</font><font style="display: inline;"> connection with the grant of non-qualified stock options, incentive stock options, and restricted stock to eligible employees, consultants and members of our Board of Directors. As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">2</font><font style="display: inline;">, &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">5.7</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million shares w</font><font style="display: inline;">ere available for future issuance under the </font><font style="display: inline;">2007</font><font style="display: inline;"> Plan.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Stock options under both the 2005 Plan and the 2007 Plan generally vest ratably over four years with the first year vesting on a &#x201C;cliff&#x201D; basis followed by monthly vesting for the remaining three years. Restricted stock awards </font><font style="display: inline;">and units </font><font style="display: inline;">generally vest annually on a straight-line basis over three or four years depending on the terms of the award agreement.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Stock Option
